docs.lead_paragraph: If anyone required further evidence that President Bush's fiscal policies have not worked the way he says they have, this week's report from the Census Bureau provided it. In brief, from 2001 through 2003, poverty increased, income stagnated and the ranks of the uninsured grew, while the United States spent some $400 billion on tax cuts, which mainly benefited wealthy families. The Bush administration seemed intent on minimizing the political impact of the report, releasing the data on Thursday, instead of the usual date in late September, to get it done before the convention. But the numbers spoke for themselves. Since Mr. Bush came to power, 4.3 million people have fallen below the poverty line, set at $18,660 for a family of four in 2003, bringing the total number of people living in poverty in 2003 to 35.9 million, or 12.5 percent of the American population. The poor will always suffer most from recession and job losses. But one sure way to stem the slide into poverty is by bolstering state programs that directly benefit the poor, like job training, health care and child care. The administration devoted only 3 percent of its stimulus spending to aid for state governments. Congress and the administration have also done nothing to enhance the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families program. As a result, while the number of children living in poverty increased by 11 percent over the past three years, the number of children receiving welfare declined by 10 percent over the same period. Adding to the gloom, median family income -- $44,853 in 2000 -- fell by $1,535 during the administration's first three years, while the number of Americans without health insurance, according to the Census Bureau, grew by 5.2 million, to 45 million in 2003. The president and Congress have largely ignored this problem, while leaving little room to address it later by ballooning the deficit with tax cuts.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sure, she is upset that she cannot afford health care, and it hurts that higher tuition costs at the community college where she carries a full load have put her deeper in debt. But at the end of this month, Molly Illingworth will suffer the worst blow yet: she is getting laid off by her mother. ''I hate to close the shop,'' says Pam DeBruyn, Molly's mother, who owns a small party and office supply store here, and also works full time as a graphic designer. She needs the designer job for the health insurance, so she will close the store, and with it will go her daughter's employment.

docs.lead_paragraph: Regulator Finds Problems At Big 4 Accounting Firms The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, which was established by Congress in 2002 as the regulatory body for the audit industry, said that its inspections of the Big Four accounting firms had found ''significant audit and accounting issues'' in work done by all four firms. The board reviewed the details of 16 audits in 2003 at each firm. It added that it had found problems in the quality control systems at each firm, but that it retained confidence in them. [Page C2.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Seizing on a new census report to bolster his argument that wages have fallen and health care costs have risen under the Bush administration, Senator John Kerry on Thursday challenged the president to weekly debates until Election Day. ''America deserves a serious discussion about its future; it does not deserve a campaign of smear and fear,'' Mr. Kerry, the Democratic presidential nominee, told several hundred people at a technical college here. ''The president and I can meet somewhere, we can have a discussion, we can stand up, we can share our thoughts.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Working Americans have two great concerns: the growing difficulty of getting health insurance, and the continuing difficulty they have in finding jobs. These concerns may have a common cause: soaring insurance premiums. In most advanced countries, the government provides everyone with health insurance. In America, however, the government offers insurance only if you're elderly (Medicare) or poor (Medicaid). Otherwise, you're expected to get private health insurance, usually through your job. But insurance premiums are exploding, and the system of employment-linked insurance is falling apart.

docs.lead_paragraph: The ranks of the poor and those without health insurance grew in 2003 for the third straight year, the government reported on Thursday, in a sign of the lingering pain being caused by a long slump in the job markets. Those trends, spelled out by the United States Census Bureau, signaled a clear shift in the way the 2001 recession and its aftermath have spread across the country. The economy's troubles, which first affected high-income families even more than the middle class and poor, have recently hurt families at the bottom and in the middle significantly more than those at the top.

headline.main: More Americans Were Uninsured And Poor in 2003, Census Finds

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City's poverty rate and median income held steady last year, while housing continued to take an ever larger chunk of New Yorkers' paychecks, according to an annual survey released yesterday by the Census Bureau. The data showed that New Jersey had the highest median income in the nation, but that several other states were in close contention; the margin of error for the survey means the ranking could change slightly.

The increase in uninsured people last year, as reported by the United States Census Bureau yesterday, was 1.4 million, to a record 45 million.

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. Conducts Searches In Move to Stop File Sharing Federal authorities conducted six searches in a move to disrupt a network used to trade copies of movies, software, games and music. The Justice Department said the searches were the first criminal enforcement action related to copyright law aimed at peer-to-peer networks. In a peer-to-peer network, like the widely used Kazaa system, the computers of individual users connect to each other to trade files without going through a central computer. The Justice Department has stepped up enforcement of copyright law this year, but until now has focused on the theft of copies of movies and other material to make them available to downloaders. [Page C4.]
